awd_titl_txt: S&AS: INT: Smart And Autonomous Systems For Repair And Improvisation
awd_abstract_narration:
Robots will be more useful to society as they respond to more natural teaching paradigms similar to the way people learn.  It is hard to tell robots what to do, and even harder to tell robots how to handle all possible errors, unanticipated events, and accidents that might happen. This project focuses on enabling robots to understand instructions from users, to fix errors and repair broken processes, objects, and tools, and to improvise and find new and better ways to do tasks. A key part of the research is to enable robots to learn from educational kits and instructional material typically given to children. The researchers plan to use these instructional materials to provide robots with "physical common sense" about how the world works, in a similar way we expect children to learn. The research will make programming robots easier and cheaper, and make robots more useful, particularly for domestic and care robots supporting everyday life activities; repair, construction, and decommissioning robots; and exploration and worker robots in the oceans and space.

Technically, this integrative project addresses a longer-term vision and intellectual challenge of developing a library approach to robot behavior generation and learning. The researchers will build a large-scale long-term intelligent physical system that can repair and improvise desired processes and devices.  The system will learn from instruction in the form of a curriculum of training tasks, watching humans do tasks, coaching, practice, less directed play, and reflection.  Evaluation of the proposed work will focus on how well robots can perform suggested activities from the instructional material, repair broken processes and devices, and create processes and devices that achieve new task specifications. The following hypotheses will be tested: 1) appropriate libraries can be built in practice and grown over time, 2) relevant experience can be accessed from a large library and combined to exhibit rich behavior comparable to humans, and 3) such a library can support life-long learning for many tasks, rather than a single demonstration of one task in one domain.  Key ideas include the use of task and strategy-specific quantitative models, the development of strategy graphs that combine both symbolic descriptions of how to do a task as well as task-level models, and the use of learned simulators to support mental practice, exploration, and learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project "S&AS: INT: Smart And Autonomous Systems For Repair And
Improvisation" made substantial progress in enabling robots to reason
for themselves, figure how to repair damage and fix problems, and
improvise to handle errors and surprises. This work will make robots
and other machines easier and less expensive to program, and more
useful to society.  One focus of the work was developing a library
approach to generating behavior. Based on the hypothesis that humans
have large libraries of useful behaviors (often referred to as
"cultural knowledge"), the project explored ways to build similar
behavior libraries for robots.  Ways to store experiences, find
similar experiences in memory, and adapt experiences to similar
situations were developed.  Another focus was strategy selection in
the context of a behavior library. There are often many ways to solve
a problem represented in a behavior library, and a robot needs to pick
the best choice, or at least a good choice. The project developed ways
to cluster experiences, and ways to choose which cluster to pay
attention to in any particular situation.  Experiences are stored
using what is sensed during the behavior. In addition to raw
sensations such as two dimensional images, more extensive information,
such as three dimensional models, are created to augment the
representation of experience. Techniques were developed to represent
the relationship and arrangement of objects in memory using scoring
functions known as "energy functions". An arrangement of objects is
scored as to how well it matches the concept of "circle", and high
scoring arrangements are referred to as circles. Objects and events
can be arranged over time (event sequences) as well as in spatially.
Computer simulations were developed to infer quantities that are not
easily measured, such as forces between objects, as well as scoring
interpretations of what happened over time as to how realistic or even
possible they are. Simulations were augmented using a technique known
as "generative modeling", in which systems were trained to predict
typical outcomes. A specific domain that was explored are articulated
objects such as doors and drawers where rigid parts can move relative
to each other.  The project developed a learning approach that
explicitly looks for and tests kinematic constraints (such as joints)
between hypothesized objects and object parts in order to parse a
scene into 3D rigid bodies with shapes, poses, and velocities.
